title: Tracking Metal/Oxide Interface Evolution and Reaction Kinetics of Fusion Energy Nanostructured Tungsten Material Using In Situ ETEM
content: Tungsten (W) is the leading candidate for nuclear fusion plasma-facing material (PFM). It is directly exposed to extremely harsh environmental conditions, including high-flux of low-energy He-plasma, high temperature, neutron irradiation, and stress. One of the critical safety concerns in fusion reactors involves aggressive high-temperature oxidation of tungsten divertor in case of loss-of-vacuum accidents (LOVAs) and loss-of-coolant accidents (LOCAs). In our prior research, we presented the pioneering in-situ observation of thermal oxidation of high-purity fusion tungsten using 1 bar environmental TEM (ETEM) [1]. Here, we explore the oxidation behavior of W nanofuzz, a prevalent and significant surface morphology alteration resulting from high-flux, low-energy He-plasma exposure [2], employing a combination of conventional thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and innovative 1 bar ETEM technique.
